Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: The deadline for closing the books for the month is approaching.
Story: I sat at my desk, the hum of the office fading into the background as I stared at two open tabs on my computer. On one screen, my colleague’s message blinked: “Hey, just checking if you’ll have the report ready by noon? I need it to finish my part.” On the other, the accounting software reminded me that the month-end close was due in just a few hours. As a colleague, I knew how much my teammate depended on my timely work—any delay from me would throw off her entire schedule. But as the accountant, I was responsible for ensuring every number in the books was accurate, and the pressure to avoid mistakes was immense. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: help my teammate keep the project on track, or focus on the financial records that couldn’t afford errors. I felt the tension tightening in my chest, torn between letting down a friend and risking a costly accounting mistake. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, uncertain which task to tackle first.
